reasoning: The critique targets a key load-bearing part of the essay’s optimism: that partial AM-convergence plus bargaining/trade can often yield mostly-great outcomes. If power concentrates into a (near-)singleton quickly, the bargaining picture and the “non-tiny minority” framing become much less relevant, so the attacked claim is moderately central (though not fully central because the essay also considers WAM-convergence, self-interest-driven routes, and explicitly flags concentration of power as a blocker). The objection is substantively plausible—AGI takeoff dynamics could collapse the bargaining set and make initial headcount fractions misleading—so it meaningfully weakens the trade-based story, but it doesn’t decisively refute it because (i) the essay already anticipates concentration-of-power and timing concerns, (ii) takeoff needn’t yield a singleton, and (iii) trade could still occur among major coalitions or within institutions prior to lock-in. Most statements are directionally correct, but some are overstated (e.g., that bargaining becomes irrelevant and the disagreement point is simply “we take all” across realistic security/coalitional/legitimacy constraints). The critique is clear, focused on one issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: Population fractions matter less than power dynamics in AGI-era bargaining
